raw_text:
Blair Labour's longest-serving PM
 
 Tony Blair has become the Labour Party's longest-serving prime minister.
 
 The 51-year-old premier has marked his 2,838th day in the post, overtaking the combined length of Harold Wilson's two terms during the 1960s and 1970s. If Mr Blair wins the next election and fulfils his promise to serve a full third term, he will surpass Margaret Thatcher's 11 years by the end of 2008. In 1997, Mr Blair became the youngest premier of the 20th century, when he came to power at the age of 43. The last prime minister to be installed at a younger age was Lord Liverpool, who was a year his junior in 1812.
 
 Mr Blair's other political firsts include becoming the first Labour leader to win two successive full terms in power after the 2001 Labour landslide. And the birth of the Blairs' fourth child, Leo, on 20 May, 2000, was the first child born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years. The last "Downing Street dad" was Lord John Russell in 1848. Labour won a huge majority of 167 over the Conservatives in 2001, but Mr Blair has since been criticised by many in his own party. The war in Iraq and reforms of the health service and education system have provoked dissent from backbenchers.
 
 Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer under Mr Blair, became Britain's longest-serving chancellor of modern times in 2004. Former Labour leader Lord Kinnock said the chancellor would be best placed to take over from Mr Blair. When asked about the future leadership of the party, he told ITV Wales' Waterfront programme: "That contest is a long way away and it will occur only when the Prime Minister, Tony Blair, decides he's subscribed all he can and then wants to go. "I think that the main contender will be Gordon Brown, who is a man of virtually unmatched capability and now great experience." Both Mr Brown and Mr Blair rose to prominence when Lord Kinnock led Labour between 1983 and 1992.
llama3.2:1b: Blair has become Labour's longest-serving prime minister with 2,838 days. He surpassed Harold Wilson's two terms in the 1960s and 1970s. If he wins the next election and serves a full third term, he will surpass Margaret Thatcher by the end of 2008. Blair became the youngest premier in the 20th century at age 43 in 1997, and his other notable firsts include leading Labour to two successive full terms after the 2001 landslide.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair has become the Labour Party's longest-serving prime minister, overtaking Harold Wilson's two terms, and will surpass Margaret Thatcher's 11 years if he wins the next election and serves a full third term. He became the youngest premier of the 20th century in 1997 at age 43, and his time in office has seen several political firsts, including winning two successive full terms in power after the 2001 Labour landslide.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair is the longest-serving Labour Party Prime Minister, surpassing Harold Wilson's tenure and on track to surpass Margaret Thatcher's record in 2008. He became the youngest PM of the 20th century upon his election in 1997.  His record includes becoming the first Labour leader to win two consecutive full terms and having the first child born to a serving Prime Minister in over a century.  He has faced criticism for decisions such as the Iraq war and healthcare reforms, and Gordon Brown, Chancellor of the Exchequer under Blair, is widely considered a strong potential successor.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tony Blair became the longest-serving prime minister in British history, with his 51st day serving as a Premier from May 2007 until June 2023. He was also the youngest PM during the 20th century when he came to power at age 43. Blair's other major political accomplishments include becoming the first Labour leader to win two successive full terms in power after the 2001 Labour landslide, and being born of a serving prime minister, Lord John Russell, in 1848. He also became Britain's longest-serving chancellor of modern times in 2004 when he was appointed by the Conservatives under Tony Blair.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair has become the longest-serving prime minister in British history, having surpassed Harold Wilson's combined term length. He will likely surpass Margaret Thatcher by the end of 2008 if he wins the next election. Other notable firsts include being the youngest prime minister at age 43 and becoming the first Labour leader to win two consecutive full terms after 2001's landslide victory, which has since been criticized internally.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair has become the longest-serving Prime Minister of the Labour Party, having served for 2,838 days as of his current term. At 51 years old, he surpassed Harold Wilson's combined terms in the late 1960s and early 1970s. If re-elected, Blair would surpass Margaret Thatcher’s 11-year tenure by end-2008. He was also the youngest Prime Minister of the 20th century at age 43 in 1997. Blair’s other firsts include becoming the first Labour leader to win two consecutive full terms and having the birth of his fourth child, Leo, which was the first birth of a serving prime minister since Lord John Russell in 1848. Critics have questioned Blair's leadership due to the war in Iraq and reforms in healthcare and education. Gordon Brown became Britain’s longest-serving Chancellor under Blair; former Labour leader Lord Kinnock suggested he would likely succeed Blair, with Gordon Brown being considered the most capable candidate.

Blair Labour's longest-serving PM

Tony Blair has become the Labour Party's longest-serving prime minister.

The 51-year-old premier has marked his 2,838th day in the post, overtaking the combined length of Harold Wilson's two terms during the 19th century and 70s. If Mr Blair wins the next election and fulfils his promise to serve a full third term, he will surpass Margaret Thatcher's 11 years by the end of 2008.

In 1997, Mr Blair became the youngest premier of the 20th century when he came to power at the age of 43. The last prime minister to be installed at a younger age was Lord Liverpool, who served only one term in 18 years. 

Mr Blair's other political firsts include becoming the first Labour leader to win two successive full terms in power after the 2001 Labour landslide. And the birth of the Blairs' fourth child, Leo, on 20 May, 2,000, was the first child born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years.

The last "Downing Street dad" was Lord John Russell in 18th century. The War in Iraq and reforms of the health service and education system have provoked dissent from backbenchers. 

Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer under Mr Blair, became Britain's longest-serving chancellor of modern times in 2004. Former Labour leader Lord Kinnock said the chancellor would be best placed to take over from Mr Blair. The program he served on, ITV Wales' Waterfront, was a long way away and it will occur only when the Prime Minister, Tony Blair, decides he's subscribed all he can and then wants to go.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve the key ideas and details of the original text:

1. The longest-serving PM in modern times is Tony Blair, who has served for a total of 2,838 days.
2. Tony Blair became the Labour Party's longest-serving prime minister in 2007 when he won the election and continued to serve until his defeat in 2010.
3. Mr Blair has also been known for his other political firsts, including becoming the first Labour leader to win two consecutive full terms in power after the 2001 Labour landslide.
4. The birth of the Blairs' fourth child, Leo, on 20 May, 2000, was the first child born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years.
5. Mr Blair has been criticized by many in his own party for his handling of the Iraq war and reforms of the health service and education system.

He won a 65% majority in 2001 against the Conservatives, but his party has criticized him. The Iraq war and health reforms have caused some criticism from Backbenchers. So putting all that together, I need to create a concise summary highlighting his longevity, achievements, the age of leadership, birth of his child, party criticism, and his successor. I should make sure it's clear and captures the key points without getting into too much detail.

Tony Blair has served as Britain's longest-serving Prime Minister, starting in 1964. Over two-thirds of Harold Wilson's tenure during the '60s and '70s was overtaken by his record 2,838th day. He became the youngest PM of the 20th century in 1997 at age 43. The first Labour leader to hold two full terms after 2001 and the first child of a serving MP since Lord Liverpool (a year older) in 2000. He won 65% majority in 2001 but faced criticism from his party, with Gordon Brown as successor.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite being the longest-serving prime minister in modern British history, Tony Blair has now marked his 2,838th day in office. His successor, Gordon Brown, was the country's longest-servicing chancellor between 2004 and 2007. The last prime minister to be installed at a younger age was Lord Liverpool, who became Prime Minister for a year in 1812. However, it has been revealed that Mr Blair surpassed this record by gaining his latest mandate with the support of a majority of Labour MPs in May 2007. Former Labour leader Gordon Brown, who is now a prominent contender for the party leadership, is expected to take over from Mr Blair when he decides he's ready to go.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Blair Labour's longest-serving PM, Tony Blair, has overtaken the combined length of Harold Wilson's two terms during the 1960s and 1970s to become the UK's longest-serving prime minister. He took over from his predecessor Margaret Thatcher in May 1997 and served a total of 2,838 days until his resignation in November 2001. Since then, the Labour Party has elected its new leader, Jeremy Corbyn, with a clear commitment to delivering a third term for Tony Blair.
phi:2.7b: Tony Blair has become the longest-serving prime minister in British history with a record-breaking 2,838 days in office. He has also achieved other firsts such as becoming the youngest premier of the 20th century and the first Labour leader to win two successive full terms in power since Labour's landslide victory in 2001. In 20001, Labour won an enormous majority of 167 over the Conservatives under Mr Blair, but he has been criticized by many within his party for his handling of the war in Iraq and reforms of the health service and education system. The next leader of the Labour Party may be Gordon Brown, who is considered one of the contenders.

In 1997, Blair became the youngest premier of the 20th century at age 43. He was also the first Labour leader to win two successive full terms in power after the 2001 landslide. The birth of his fourth child, Leo, in 2000 marked the first child born to a serving prime minister in more than 150 years. Gordon Brown, who served as chancellor under Blair, became Britain's longest-serving chancellor of modern times in 2004. granite3.1-dense:2b:
Tony Blair, at 51 years old, has served as the longest-serving Labour prime minister, exceeding Harold Wilson's two terms in the 1960s and 1970s. If he wins the next election and completes a full third term, he will surpass Margaret Thatcher's record of 11 years by late 2008. Mr. Blair became prime minister at 43 in 1997, making him the youngest in the 20th century, surpassing Lord Liverpool (1812). He is the first Labour leader to win two consecutive full terms after a 2001 landslide victory. The birth of his fourth child, Leo, in 2000, marked the first time a serving prime minister had a child in over 150 years.

Mr. Blair's tenure has been marked by criticism from within his party due to the Iraq war and reforms of healthcare and education. Gordon Brown, chancellor since 2004, is considered the most likely successor, according to Lord Kinnock, who led Labour from 1983 to 1992 under Mr. Blair's premiership. Both men rose together during this period.
reference: Both Mr Brown and Mr Blair rose to prominence when Lord Kinnock led Labour between 1983 and 1992.Former Labour leader Lord Kinnock said the chancellor would be best placed to take over from Mr Blair.Tony Blair has become the Labour Party's longest-serving prime minister.Labour won a huge majority of 167 over the Conservatives in 2001, but Mr Blair has since been criticised by many in his own party.Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer under Mr Blair, became Britain's longest-serving chancellor of modern times in 2004.In 1997, Mr Blair became the youngest premier of the 20th century, when he came to power at the age of 43.
